Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Metanumerical Computing for Emerging Architectures: Automated Embedded Algorithms for Partial Differential Equations on Multicore Platforms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Computers were invented to automate tedious and error-prone
tasks, especially in the context of numerical calculations for
scientific simulation. Given the importance and difficulty of
developing these simulations, it makes sense to study whether
computers can assist in their production as well. This project
focuses on the open-source project Sundance, which provides
high-level syntax to describe finite element methods (FEM) for the
numerical solution of partial differential equations, freeing users
from the burdens of low-level programming. This approach can reduce
development time from months to days or even hours, allowing
scientists and engineers to get correct answers more quickly.
Sundance is useful software starting from a solid theoretical basis,
where the structure of finite element operators are derived and
analyzed from software-based Frechet differentiation of variational
forms.

Via this domain-specific embedded language, Sundance users (domain
scientistis and engineers) can express and simulate nonlinear processes
with little more difficulty than linear ones; Jacobians are calculated
internally and automatically. This robust system automates not only
standard simulations, but also sensitivity calculations, eigenvalue
problems, and PDE-constrained optimization, all through the language of
differentiation, providing a simple gateway to efficient ``embedded''
algorithms for optimization and control. Furthermore, in this project,
Sundance will be extended to run on emerging architectures such as
multicore CPU and GPU machines. New low-complexity finite element
algorithms based on Bernstein polynomials will be developed and included
within Sundance to further exploit this new hardware. Thus, this project
represents concrete transformational contributions not only automating
mathematical software but in core numerical algorithms, broadening the
circle of domain specialists with access to leading-edge simulation
technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computers were invented in part to automate tedious and error-pronetasks, especially for the massive scale of arithmetic calculationsrequired for realistic scientific simulation.  However, architecturaladvances such as multi- and many-core processors make the programmingof computers an increasingly tedious and error-prone task.  Hence,it becomes all the more important to study ways in which computersthemselves can expedite the production of mathematical software.
We refer to the study of numerical algorithms focused on findinginternal structure suitable for the manipulation, generation, andoptimization of their implementations as metanumerical computing.It has been the focus of this project to study such software,including possible next-generation algorithms and novel applications.
Regarding emerging architectures, we have provided new results onfinite element algorithms for GPU and multicore CPU architectures.With collaborators, we have implemented finite element integration ata high fraction of peak performance and also shown how to assembleelement matrices in parallel without data transfer.  We have also studiedthe solution of resulting linear systems using the Trilinos project fromSandia National Laboratories.
On the front of metanumerical software proper, we have worked with andapplied high-level codes such as FEniCS and Sundance that convert high-leveldescriptions of partial differential equations into effective implementations.However, recognizing certain limitations of the generated algorithms forhigh-order approximation and many novel methods, we have also begun thedevelopment of a new project called FInAT, which allows programmers tospecify abstract syntax for desired algorithms.  We hope that future workwill bring these ideas to fruition, leading to far more flexible andefficient metanumerical codes.
With regard to applications, we have given analysis of novel methodsfor wave equations arising in acoustics and tidal modeling.  We havealso studied preconditioners for various problems in fluid mechanics andbegun a study of a coupled system arising in photoacoustic spectroscopy.This breadth begins to demonstrate the power of metanumerical computingto rapidly deploy powerful numerical algorithms to importantcontemporary problems in computational science.
